posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>Sports

Agreed. But only because Sega of America tried really hard. Sega of Japan didn't care about sports.


>dedicated "amusement ride" machines
>Sega

Agreed. But ONLY because Namco pulled out of the amusement ride market in the 90s. If you read interviews, Namco Execs decided that, it was a bad idea financially to keep fighting Sega for building giant amusement rides. Namco could continue, but it had been doing so for 15 years against Sega with no clear winner. Sega was also getting reckless and spending huge amounts of money to beat Namco's amusement rides. If Namco built a ride, then Sega would build one too and make it bigger and more expensive.
Namco felt like it was getting it was a never ending battle and would just drain money.

So after making the big Galaxian 16 amusement ride and Ridge Racer Full Scale, I believe Namco stopped and strategically withdrew. Sega then took over the market but Sega was bankrupted by the effort.

>>9506168
>bullsht, sega owned spas and shit, they didn't go backrupt

Bro... Sega went into DEEP debt during the 1990s. They spent ridiculous amounts of money. They overspent way more money than that actually had. All in an effort to beat Namco, Nintendo, and Sony. Sega was not super rich company. They just had really good marketing.

Sega was literally about to declare bankruptcy in 2001. It was all over the gaming news. The Sega Dreamcast failed and it was the final last straw that broke Sega. Banks wouldn't lend Sega anymore money. They were in the red. It was over. Sega was finished.

Right before Sega about to collapse and declare bankruptcy, the Sega CEO (Isao Okawa) donated his ENTIRE family fortune of $750 million dollars to save Sega. His final words as CEO was "I love Sega. I love the Dreamcast. I will not let Sega die."

This donation helped Sega pay off their debts and kept them alive while they left the console market and became a 3rd Party Game developer. Isao Okawa died only a few months later. Sega built a statue in his honor and is considered a hero that saved the company.

Sega isn't doing so hot these days either. They sold their entire Japanese arcade business in 2020. Meanwhile Namco held onto their arcade business. Namco won the arcade war after 40 years of competition with Sega.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9507280
>Remeber when all the companies used they own proprietary boards which made their games look unique to each other. Then they all started using basic bitch off the shelf pc parts

Yeah but the downside these arcade machines cost tens of thousands of dollars when they came out. And some of those boards were also brittle or poorly made. Sega Model 3 and Hikaru boards were notorious for having so many problems. Hikaru boards especially were bad because they were known for breaking because of bad solder joints. Capacitors would literally break off the board when arcade businesses tried to move the machine to another part of the building in a normal move. It was so bad that Sega discontinued them only after a few games were made with them, and arcade owners complained to Sega about poor quality.

Those boards use proprietary parts. They are incredibly difficult to repair because the only way to fix them is to get Sega or Namco to warranty fix it. Or find another same arcade board and salvage parts from.

Once Sega and Namco stop offering warranty repairs, many arcades would just throw out the machines once they break because it was such a headache to keep the machines going. That's why some Arcades are so rare today.

Once arcade manufacturers switched to using standard PC parts, it became much easier to preserve and maintain the arcade machines.

Keep in mind that games like Snatcher, Policenauts and Metal Gear all Japanese PC games, originally. Snatcher was remade for the PCE-CDROM in Japan, and that version was ported to the Sega CD (without Kojima) for English regions only. The Sega CD version was somewhat remade for the Japanese Saturn and PS1. Policenauts was remade for the 3DO in Japan originally, and the 3DO version was ported to the Japanese Saturn and PS1. Metal Gear had some success on the NES, and Metal Gear Solid was originally planed for the 3DO, but ultimately ended up on the PS1. The TMNT arcade games were great arcade beat 'em up's though. Konami really shifted to the home console market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
None of you know your gaming history at all. Namco was ALWAYS the #1 seller in arcades in the 1980s and 1990s. Especially in Japan Namco was King. They were bigger and more financially stable than Sega.

Sega while big too was the underdog company bitterly chasing after Namco. Namco was #1 in sales, but Sega was a close #2. Sega would spend huge amounts of money in trying invent bigger and better games than Namco. The Sega/Namco rivalry was intense and legendary. Namco and Sega constantly one upping eachother and stealing eachother employees.
Namco remained number #1, but Sega pushed them really, really, really hard. Namco had to constantly innovate to keep their top spot.

Namco even thought about releasing their own home console in the 1990s to compete with Sega for the home console market. But cooler heads at Namco prevailed. The Namco Executives felt that it would financially reckless to spread themselves too thin like Sega was doing.

Namco then decided to ONLY focus on three main things. Making console games, arcade cabinets, and running their Namco arcades/theme parks. In addition, Sony paid Namco a lot of money to exclusively make games for the Sony Playstation. So it made more financial sense to support Sony rather than make their own console.

Meanwhile Sega was spending HUGE amounts of money making console games, arcade games, making home consoles (Sega Genesis, Saturn, etc), pinball machines, huge Sega Theme parks, sponsoring Sega Race car teams, making Sega Brand Toys, dumping huge amounts of money into marketing to compete with Nintendo and Sony, and several other things.

Namco ended up being correct. Sega had spread themselves too thin. Sega had almost went bankrupt and went into DEEP debt. While Namco was stable and financially secure. Namco even tried to buy Sega during the early 2000s. But a damn PACHINKO company called Samy beat Namco. Samy bought Sega instead. We could have almost had a "Namco-Sega" or Namga.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9510557
>Sega of course. Why is that even a question? Namco was LITERALLY know as the company that made clones of whatever Sega did at the time.

To be fair, Sega was chasing Namco a lot too...
Namco - Rolling Thunder (1986):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ADEF8Uue7_0
Sega - Shinobi (1987):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lqScgMHVe3c

In many ways Rolling Thunder started this genre. But even Rolling Thunder took inspiration from Elevator Action. The original arcade Shinobi was Sega's version of Rolling Thunder.

Namco - Mappy (1983):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X08oIPJPFX8
Sega - Flicky (1984):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q0DactXaCHM
Mappy was a big hit for Namco. Flicky was clearly Sega's version. Flicky is a lot less well known, but the character was merged into the Sonic universe.

Namco- Winning Run (1988)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4oxvAoZmPdw
Sega - Virtua Racing (1992):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ssPfEPaTaGo
Now Sega's Virtua Racing came out a few years after Winning Run. But Virtua Racing would not exist if Namco didn't do it first. I think it took a while for Sega to develop their own 3D hardware to do it. Before Virtua Racing, almost all of Sega's '3D' games were super scaler games.

On the Sega side, Tekken was developed by a former Sega employee who worked on the original Virtua Fighter. Time Crisis was a response to Virtua Cop, but at the same time, it was also originally meant to be another game in the Rolling Thunder series. The cover mechanic was inspired by Rolling Thunder. These are just a few examples I can think of.

>>9512079
>it was a third pillar

I remember being on the NeoGAF forums in 2003 and reading the flame wars between the Sonyfanbots and Nintendodoids (or whatever they were called) around the PSP and DS. Sony announced the PSP first. Then Nintendo made an announcement that they were making a new handheld that would have two screens, shortly after. Which lead to a lot of speculation. Before both systems were released, people thought that Sony was going to crush Nintendo in the handheld market. But it turned out to be the opposite, as the DS dominated, and the PSP still sold really well. Because the GBA really was selling well with a lot of third party support, Nintendo made that 'the DS will be out third pillar" comment. In the end, the GBA still sold well alongside the DS and DS having backwards compatibility with the GBA helped a lot. People were buying GBA games for their DS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As far as I know Nintendo's handhelds always did really well for them. They iterated a lot on the hardware. Even the GameBoy Color wasn't really a platform of its own--it was the umpteenth version of the GameBoy. If anything, for the relatively short cycle of its life as the most current Nintendo handheld, it sure had a lot of longevity, success, and a big library of good games.

It seems silly to say this but technology was advancing so rapidly then, in such an immediately noticeably way. It seemed amazing to have something akin to the SNES in your pocket and then in only a few years the DS and the PSP were just shy of their console counterparts, for the most part. No doubt helped by the screen size.

Now Nintendo has no second pillar, but what they have produced is likely on its way to becoming the best selling game console of all time. But I do wonder if they would ever introduce another pillar, a separate and distinct hardware. I'm assuming the next thing will be a close iteration of the Switch though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9511374
The first one is a bit punishing in difficulty, and a bit one note, but it's also fun in an arcade-like sort of way. Once you get a knack for the driving, and the awkward aiming and shooting (or secure a machinegun and lots of ammo so that you don't have to aim), it gets increasingly fun.
You basically grind for score by doing missions and activities, but the game makes it work with its colorful graphics and mission dialogue. If you fuck up a mission, you don't get another chance at it, but there's always lots of missions and activities to do.

It is. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9502440
vanilla > limit removing (crispy) > boom > MBF21 > Zdoom > GZdoom
each is backwards compatible with the ones before it, and at every level you can have dehacked scripts, which is why knee deep in knee deep in zdoom has so many gameplay changes while being "vanilla"
SOME dehacked is incompatible with GZDoom but those exceptions are usually well documented and the wad author will have a disclaimer saying it does not work in GZDoom

Gonna copy and paste /vm/'s guide and replace relevant bits:
So, if you want to yell at your fellow racers and call them some slurs, here's what you need to do:
1. Install the Mumble client - https://dl.mumble.info/latest/stable/client-windows-x64
2. Enable the "Link" plugin by doing the following:
Configure -> Settings
Plugins -> Tick "Link to Game and Transmit position" -> Tick "Enable" for the "Link" plugin in the plugins list -> Click Apply
3. Connect to the /srb2k/ mumble server:
>Address: 51.161.34.159
>Port: (leave as default)
>Username: (whatever you want i guess)
4. You should be put into a room with other racers. At this point, you're good to boot up the game and join the server.

If everything is set up correctly, the proximity chat should be instant once you get into a game.

In case you forgot, the server IP is 51.161.34.159

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9506183
>I've seen it and Doom 3 receive the most lukewarm response out of the pre-360 Idsoft shooters.
I really don't remember the lukewarm response for Q2. On single player front it was overshadowed by HL and Unreal and in multiplayer it hit moral obsolescence when Q3 came out, but i don't remember anyone honestly calling Q2 a bad game even after that - people just moved on to different titles.
>>9506136
>Quake 2 hate isn't recent, it's always been seen as the weakest id FPS
Compared to the game's age, it is. I am confident that people that trash talk Q2 nowadays are just unloading their grief about the breakup of id's rockstar duo of Carmack and Romero because Q2 had the bad luck of being the first id game that started development after that. I understand their feelings - just like Pink Floyd without Waters, id just wasn't the same anymore. But Q2 definitely wasn't seen as weaker than Q1 back in the day by anyone except maybe Lovecraft fans that were salty about the change in art direction. It got great reviews, it was a hit in multiplayer and had several very influential mods, for some time it was a definitive benchmark, and idTech2 was probably the most successeful engine of its era on the market. Yeah, in hindsight it is not id's best work, but it still has stronger design than Doom 3 and a great game nonetheless.
>at least before Rage existed.
Rage was the first id game that public had generally negative opinion about after launch (Doom 3 avoided that). It was also the first id game to be loudly criticized. At this point id lost the godlike reputation that it had in the 90s, and Rage was the first id game that failed to innovate at least in some way - most criticisms boiled down to failures of megatexture and the unfavorable comparisons with Borderlands that did everything Rage tried to do but better and a year earlier. Saying that, none of the mentioned games are explicitly bad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507007
>Chocolate Doom
As you've said the main focus there is staying as vanilla as possible, which means pwad compatibility isn't huge and there aren't any extra features

>Crispy Doom
This one is close to vanilla but can also play limit-removing vanilla compatible maps (examples: Scythe 2, JPCP, Auger Zenith), and has those qol features like widescreen support, an option to disable the FPS limit and enable a slightly higher but still old looking resolution setting, colored blood, brightmaps.

>Prboom+
Can play Boom and MBF maps (examples: Eviternity, Skillsaw wads, Sunlust, Community Chest series), you can also set any resolution you want and use a hardware renderer.

>Woof
Basically Crispy Doom + Prboom+, compatible with all those maps, but still limited to low resolution and also has some of the features from Crispy Doom that Prboom+ lacks (brightmaps and colored blood)

When playing Woof or Prboom+ you'll have to set up the complevel launch command depending on what exact type of compatibility settings you want, since Boom/MBF change some of the original game's behavior. In Prboom+ it should be -complevel 2 for vanilla, -complevel 9 for Boom wads and -complevel 11 for MBF wads. In Woof if I remember right it should be simply -complevel vanilla/boom/mbf. Oh and there's also the new MBF21 thing, which both Woof and new Prboom+ versions support too. (-complevel 21 and -complevel mbf21)

posts.com:
PSA for Quake nappers: If you're using TB, you might be frustrated like me because no prefabs. Use Net Radiant Custom in conjunction with it:
https://github.com/Garux/netradiant-custom
>NRC?
Fork of the oldest Quake mapping tools, but the real shit of it is the robust prefabs system.

Note: I imagine most of you who have been mapping for a while have your own folder or .map of prefabs so this probably won't be useful to you.

You just draw a box in NRC, select the brush tab, and you can give it as many sides as you need to instantly with the prism option for instant pillars, octagons; or the instant sphere button, instant ROCK button, instant isodecahedron button, it's ridiculous. You can also use the polygon button (rock button top right corner) to just make instantly carved out objects of any number of sides.

Once you've got what you want, just save the object somewhere and open the .map created in TB and voila, you can copy and paste.
>Doesn't JACK have a similar system?
Yes, in fact JACK has an instant arch and spiral stairs feature but you have to buy it on Steam. There's a free version available but I think it's more limited. Still I do like JACK.
>Why not just use NRC or JACK instead of TB?
NRC lacks at the moment the capability to load fgds that aren't the original Quake. Plus TB's texture alignment features are just unmatched by either program.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Doom-Inspired Gumbo

Ingredients:

3 pounds sausage meatballs
1 onion, diced
2 cloves garlic, minced
2 large carrots, diced
1 bell pepper, diced
12 jalapeno peppers, chopped in half
1 quart chicken broth
1 can diced tomatoes
1 pound shrimp, peeled and deveined
2 cups cooked white rice
1 teaspoon paprika
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon chili powder
Salt and pepper to taste
Instructions:

In a large pot, cook the sausage meatballs over medium heat until browned on all sides. Remove the meatballs from the pot and set aside.
In the same pot, add the onion, garlic, carrots, bell pepper, and jalapeno peppers. Cook until the vegetables are softened, about 5-7 minutes.
Add the chicken broth, diced tomatoes, and cooked sausage meatballs to the pot. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer.
Add the shrimp, cooked white rice, paprika, cumin, chili powder, salt, and pepper to the pot. Stir to combine.
Simmer the gumbo for at least 20 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender and the flavors have melded together.
Serve the gumbo hot, with a side of white rice, cornbread, or oats.

To make The Double Barreled Doom Dog, you will need:

>2 red hot sausages
>Spicy ground mustard
>Large sourdough bun
>Pickled horseradish
>Relish
Hot sauce

Instructions:

>Preheat a grill or a griddle over medium-high heat.
>Place the sausages on the grill or griddle and cook until they are charred and black on all sides.
>While the sausages are cooking, slice the large sourdough bun in half and spread a generous amount of spicy ground mustard on one side.
>Once the sausages are fully cooked, place them side by side on the prepared bun.
>Top the sausages with pickled horseradish, relish, and hot sauce, to taste.
>Serve the Doom Dogs hot, with your choice of sides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I would say it depends on how much you want to commit yourself to the genre.

If you want to dip your feet in with a short (for an RPG), fun, well-made game, you really can't go wrong with Chrono Trigger.
I wouldn't skip it just because it looks childish; like pretty much all RPGs by Square the story becomes more and more intense as it progresses. If you stick with it you'll see what I mean.
Some other good "just visiting" titles are Madou Monogatari Hanamaru Daiyouchienji and Tenchi Souzou.

On the other hand, if you want to sink your teeth into an unforgettable massive sprawling empire of an RPG, whatever the flaws, SNES is THE place to start Megami Tensei.
I'd recommend starting with Shin Megami Tensei as it's a lot more polished than Kyuuyaku. (Kyuuyaku is a remake of the first two titles of the series. Shin is the third entry.) From there you can go into SMT 2, Kyuuyaku, or Majin I & II. You can also try If, which leads into the Persona branch that starts on PSX.
These games are all flawed for one reason or another but they are such a crazy ride. I'm honestly a little jealous of people who are just getting into RPGs for being able to play these games completely blind; I got hit with too many spoilers to be really shocked at how insane these games get.
SNES also has a really good route to get into Fire Emblem. You start with FE3 (Mystery of the Emblem), where the first half of the game is a full remake of FE1, and then you just play through the rest of the series in order until FE10. Fire Emblem is also quite flawed but I feel the amazing scale of the journey from FE3-10 somewhat helps make up for the (numerous and varied) issues.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: the fact is that everything is in a perpetual state of decay. discs, cartridges, they will all eventually degrade. the question is how quickly, and that's determined entirely by what they're made of, how they're kept, and what they've been exposed to. there are discs which are already rotten, and discs that will last 500 years. this is why data is so important: data is the only thing which cannot be destroyed. technology should be maintained for as long as possible so we can study it and digitize it, but you have to come to grips with the fact that a lot of this stuff will become inoperable within your lifetime.

If you can beat the alien spaceship without dying, you have something like 60 grenades and a full flame shot for the final boss (just jump over the Drop Shot right at the end when you get the walker with the double jump), and you can dodge his attacks by jumping in and out of the Metal Slug. The flame shot alone can take out half his HP (he is at the mid point when your ally in the saucer shows up). the grenades you can throw in from point blank but then you risk getting hit by his attacks.
It's a case of "be quick or be dead". You should be having huge damage potential there, you just have to be good enough to unload it.

also occasionally when dodging, it spawns a machinegun which you can run into by accident, which lowers your DPS a lot.

>>9505650
NTA but You are a little off. Carpal tunnel is caused by repeated gripping hand motions *with your wrist hyper extended*. They key is the wrist being extended and flexed. So pretty much people who grip gaming controllers (Xbox, Playstation, etc) tightly. Or PC gamers who grip their mice tightly.

This isnt the case with those people use larger arcade joysticks. You rest your wrist on the arcade stick box itself when playing. You aren't flexing your wrist muscles and tendons. Thus greatly reducing the risk carpal tunnel.

It's why they sell "ergonomic" keyboards and mice pads. The kind that have pads where you can rest your wrist on them while using a keyboard or mouse. The key to stop carpal tunnel is keeping the wrist relaxed and resting in something.

>Was anyone peeved about how different it was from 1? Or were sequels being very different from the original was a much more accepted standard back then, like Zelda II?

I swear, nobody really noticed that it was localized from another game. Even though Mario 2 was a bit weird and different, it was kinda the norm for Nintendo sequels to be a bit different. Also, the dream sequence helps it. Nintendo actually made a lot of merch for Mario Bros. 2, I remeber a kid in my school wearing a Super Mario Bros. 2 t-shirt, with Mario in the 'super jump' position. You know, when you crouch long enough and the character starts glowing. Also, the first DiC Mario Cartoon (Super Mario Bros. Super Show) was basically a combination of Mario 1 and Mario 2:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BkWYP95WbbY

The first Mario game was already kinda dream-like and weird. So the weirdness of this game went by barely noticed. But for me, I thought Mario 2 was an improvement over Mario 1 in so many ways. Better looking graphics, bigger maps, you could move in all directions, the pick up and throw mechanic was neat, I liked the 4 character option. Going from Mario 2 to 3 was a bit jarring, as Mario 3 is the actual evolution of Mario 1 and 2 (JP), and Mario 3 did incorporate some of the grab and throw mechanics, but was also a step back for me as a kid. Like why did it go back to just Mario and no 4 character option? Mario couldn't pick up and throw anything like he could in Mario 2. i think by the time Mario World came out, I remember reading about Mario 2 being Doki Doki Panic in Japan. Which started to make more sense.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9510973
>Was anyone peeved about how different it was from 1? Or were sequels being very different from the original was a much more accepted standard back then, like Zelda II?

I think the reaction would have been much worse if Nintendo released SMB2 Japan in the US. especially in 1987-1988, when SMB2J looked crusty and outdated compared to games like Castlevania and Mega Man. Howard Phillips made the right call when he suggested that they just convert Doki Doki into Mario 2 instead. The general reception for Mario 2 was really positive. The game looked good for a NES game in 1988, sprites looked more cartoony. I think the game being a bit easier made it preferred over Mario 1. I don;t think anyone really noticed, given the fantasy book like setting of Mario 1. The only anger came from the cartridge shortages in 1988.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me SMB2 is the one.

I believe it is the game where finally a certain threshold has been breached where creativity was finally let loose. In the game of the period usually you know what you're going to get out of the game from the get-go. Games had simple concepts and 5 seconds with the game would almost always tell you exactly what the game has to offer through its entirety.
But with SMB2, a game was finally made where you don't know what you're going to get. It managed to be creative but also keep you guessing and the fact is uses "dream world logic" means it can go every which way.
It opened the door to games being creative endeavors where things can change on the go and what you initially thought you're going to get might change and evolve through the course of the game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9511987
They're gimmicky revisions of Vampire Savior. Vampire Hunter 2 is Night Warriors/Vampire Hunter using the Vampire Savior engine. Vampire Savior 2 is Vampire Savior with some characters swapped out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9511987
Theyr'e a minor revision of VSAV. And they're basically just two halves of the same game, the only difference is which characters are missing (this is because the CPS2 board didn't have enough ROM capacity for the graphics for all 18 characters; same reason 3 characters were cut going into VSAV in the first place.) Most of the changes were considered to be for the worse, so they were generally passed in favor of the original VSAV. You can still find a very, very small playerbase for them, but VSAV is where the majority of the series' players go.

posts.sub: Quality of life improvements rom hacks
posts.com:
This hack for Castlevania modernizes the control scheme to make it more like Symphony of the Night and Mega Man, allowing the player more control while in the air.

Complete list of changes:

Enables the player to control their x-velocity in mid-air while jumping (including while jump-attacking).
(optional) When releasing the jump button, one immediately starts falling again; this allows the player to make smaller hops if desired.
After being knocked back, the player regains control after a split second and can angle their fall.
When walking off an edge, the player retains control instead of dropping straight down.
The player can jump off of stairs at any point in the climb.
(optional) The player can land on stairs.
(Optional) A bit of inertia while moving in the air.
Similar to the Akumajou Densetsu (Castlevania 3) hack here and Castlevania 2 hack found here.

Use Lunar IPS to apply the hack to your Castlevania 3 ROM file.

Version 1.1 changes:

Now compatible with Ultimate Castlevania and The Holy Relics. [i]Please ensure that you use the correct patch from the zip (other-hacks and the-holy-relics respectively) if you combine this hack with other hacks.[i]
Version 3.0 changes:

Now compatible with many other romhacks as well (see the folder for compatibility with other hacks)
Stair landing
Optional inertia for “weightier” jumps.
Individual changes can be selected.
Version 3.1 changes:

Changed folder layout of zip file to be less confusing. Previously, many would-be-players were incorrectly applying the patch for the vanilla version of the game onto hacked versions of the game.

>>9503253
I think others have said this already but to elaborate
1. Outsold hard by PCE and SFC—see >>9495753 . Mega Drive had just 3.6 mln units sold in Japan (4.4 if you count Mega CD too). Meanwhile, SFC had about 16 mln by 1995, and PCE had ~8 mln (of which 6 were PCE and 1.9 mln of Turbo Duo, also add 0.9 mln of CD-ROM2).
Basically, that means that MD was at most just 15% of the market, and SFC was like 60%, rest was PCE. So it was like the situation with Saturn vs PSX and N64 in the West. Few big companies wanted to make original games for it, because there was no reason to.
Small install base, tiny game sales in the order of ~200k for big hits (see >>9495731 ). All this meant it was unfeasible to make an RPG for MD alone, unless we're talking ports.
2. The console was just the worst fit for RPGs out of the 3. SFC was the obvious most popular choice (biggest brand, Square & Enix, fitting hardware). PCE came out earlier, already had a more popular CD add-on, meaning that it would attract most of the RPG devs that weren't satisfied with Nintendo for some reason, and/or wanted the benefits of the CD.
MD was made for fast-paced arcades. It had no real advantage over competition when it came to RPGs. Also, no one mentioned this yet, but there's this weird thing that few games on MD had saves to begin with.
Maybe that's why most 3rd party devs like Treasure were making fast arcade action games for the platform.
^With all that said, RPGs still dominated the sales of MD games (see >>9495731
and >>9495735 ), which is kind of ironic. Goes to show that RPGs were a huge deal in Japan in 4th-5th gen.

"Not as many as competing platforms" and "JP only JRPGs" =! thin

Also, ignoring the retards posting bullshit like "muh SNES allowed for muh cinematic presentation", it was the residual success of JRPGs on NES that naturally transferred over to SNES. Since shit like SMT, DQ, and FF got their start on Famicom and were huge on that platform, it was natural to continue their successes on Nintendo's next platform. Sega didn't have a gallery of RPG hits like that besides Phantasy Star on Master System, plus their adherence to "bringing the arcade home" with its faster processor encouraged more devs to go for more conventional genres (shooters, platformers) than make slow games like RPGs. Also didn't help the PC Engine got a head start allowing it to build up an audience that eventually want more genres including RPGs, and publishers fed up with Nintendo would naturally go there first.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9506664
A common myth is that the Mega Drive 2 lacks a Z80 — the truth is that it has a Z80 in a QFP-44 form factor, which is not immediately identifiable compared to the DIP Z80 used in the original Mega Drive. If the Z80 was missing, most games would have no sound (or not all sound). Beginning with the VA4 board revision, the Z80 was integrated into a custom ASIC which also incorporated the major chips of the system. My model 2 has no problem playing mega drive games.

>Genesis had a two year head start on SNES to begin with, so it is "fair" to give SNES those extra quarters to "count" towards sales and market share. Also fact: during the lives of the Genesis and SNES, SNES sold more, millions more.
I think you greatly overstate the success of SNES. Numbers do vary, some sources say Genesis sold 17-18.5 million, other say 24 mln. see https://vgsales.fandom.com/wiki/Fourth_generation_of_video_games#North_America , they give sources to each claim about numbers.
according to them, at the end of 1995, Genesis was sitting at 19.5 mln, and SNES was at 17.5 mln. there's still a lot of discussion regarding poor sources for the Wikipedia numbers, see https://www.sega-16.com/forum/archive/index.php/t-9132.html .
Even then, in the beginning of 1994, Genesis games were routinely outselling SNES ones.
Regarding the "early release advantage", from Wikipedia:
>Tasked by Nakayama to sell one million units within the first year, Katz and Sega of America sold only 500,000.
Also:
>In large part due to the popularity of Sonic the Hedgehog, the Genesis outsold the SNES in the United States nearly two to one during the 1991 holiday season. Sega controlled 65% of the 16-bit console market in January 1992, the first time Nintendo had not been the console leader since 1985.

>>9509514
the two consoles have nothing in common. the CPU, sound, control inputs, and graphics hardware are completely different, and since most SNES/MD games were coded in assembly language, you couldn't even reuse basic game algorithms like on 5th gen and up consoles where coding is done in C. that was why a lot of cross-platform games weren't actually ports but would be redone from the ground up and in effect be two different games with the same name.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I agree on the marketing point. This is an interesting thread to see how history gets confusing and subjective in such a short time.
But anyway, here's my anecdotal account that will be objectively wrong:
I'm pushing 40 so I was a kid and just didn't know or care about Sega or even SNES RPGs. Despite the satanic panic stuff, I managed to get Pen & Paper RPGs. And I was aware of King's Quest and Ultima and later Legends of Valour and so on.

Point is I thought RPG games were tabletop or PC and whatever was on consoles was not interesting or worth the weirdly higher price vs some other games. I never used my precious rental option on an RPG. I don't remember any glossy magazine feature selling me on them. I was a Sega kid, but I watched a friend play Chrono Trigger and Earthbound (yes he's a rich pretentious prick) on the SNES and my takeaway was...
>OK? When do you get to make creative or interesting decisions in action or dialogue?

So word of mouth didn't work on me. Eventually after the Genesis was basically dead we got a decent PC and I played stuff like Daggerfall, and Fallout.
So I was convinced console RPGs were baby games in their own weird category I wouldn't like. Until, I got a Dreamcast and Played Skies of Arcadia. Anyway I'm sure I'm a poor pleb with shit taste but the point of my blog is I don't think Sega focused their marketing energy hard enough on explaining the genre or value to kids. Because I can absolutely see how wrong I was and how many great games they had now now that the dust has settled into my bones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9504421
You ever think why the developers put in stuff in Super Metroid like a working mini-map that completes with exploration, and an X-ray scope or power bombs to discover hidden items and passages?

Because navigating the original Metroid was tedious. It's not even a matter of "the player should just remember or draw their own map", but the original Metroid heavily re-used screens to save on ROM space.

There's a section of Kraid's lair that is the exact same three corridors on loop with no payoff for exploring it. It's a drain to get through them with how many enemies there are in there, so this place only serves to waste the player's time and serve as a source of frustration.

The devs knew this when developing Zero Mission and adapted this area to be important to game progress; it features a mini-boss and a mechanism to activate ziplines, plus a few extra items including two missile expansions and an energy tank.

The point I'm making was that this was Nintendo R&D1's first crack at making this kind of game and the weaknesses in technology and game design are apparent, and they've deliberately avoided these mistakes for future entries in the series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507180
When playing something like Super Metroid, rooms are generally designed to be unique with landmarks, but they also give the player space to breathe. This allows the player to better exercise or develop spatial awareness, and have less challenge doing so as it's less labyrinthine.

In NES Metroid, a lot of the player's focus is put on surviving constantly respawning enemies, so it takes concentration away from observing and learning their surroundings. The design isn't memorable due to heavy repetition and re-use of chunks of map.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507210
That area is also very easy to explore in full, leave the way you came, and then remember. This runs completely against your point that you should be drawing a map.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507240
In practice, getting through these rooms is time consuming. Granted it's not a lot of space to explore, but the concentration of enemies slows you down considerably in a game where you're constantly farming energy drops against how quickly you can lose it.

So to say it's "very easy to explore in full" is facetious.

Also, "Draw your own map" isn't the point I'm making, it's the point that others often make when defending the repetitive and labyrinthine NES Metroid map.
Whilst that can be a valid play experience, it's a form of tedium to keep bringing software gameplay to a halt so you can bring out graphing paper on a clipboard or something. It's a step beyond writing down old passwords.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9506023
>it's a form of tedium
It's not tedious, you can navigate easily by counting. In the screenshot, there are three identical corridors, but as you move vertically down the main corridor you can count them, one, two, three. So, they look the same, but by counting you can locate yourself in either the 1st, 2nd or 3rd corridor. This is actually cool and immersive and the game messes with your mind, you begin questioning yourself, "did I count two corridors, or did I count three corridors?", and the repetitive music plays a factor in the overall hypnotic effect of the experience. Super Metroid is more accessible and it is more successful too because although it they added QoL features like the minimap, there are many other ways that they introduced to mess with the player, but the repetitive corridors of the original Metroid are a feature, not a design flaw. It would be nice if newer games had these sorts of tricky aspects that make the player rely on their own faculties of reasoning rather then cosseting the player from the moment the game is switched on to the moment it's switched off.

Wobbly Life on steam. Not retro, but worth every dollar. Local coop too. I see people describing it as GTA for kids, but it's not. It's just a sandbox game where you can set a task for the gaming session, and go and complete it, and it's fun. eg. Okay Kiddo, today we're going to go hunt in the jungle for artifacts and take them to the museum. Done. Next sesh, today we will go fishing.

You earn money doing jobs/quests and spend the money on buying clothes and outfits. My daughter has loved it for 2 years now and still wants to play it. The devs keep updating it too.

It's the best dad/daughter game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9504560
It's kind of like an airport novel simulator, stealth obstacle courses mixed in with think on your feet setpieces, one of the better examples being a situation where you're in a data room getting some hacking macguffin and guards are about to breach and you need to cleverly come up with a hiding spot using the environment.
on the downside it has a lot of THAT levels and THAT segments, some shitty forced combat encounters. robotic guard behavior that's a solid step below what you see in the metal gears on the ps2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9504560
Third person camera, you use your mousewheel to adjust the speed of movement. You hide in the dark. You use night vision and thermal goggles. You avoid enemies because combat is lethal. You have guns but ammo is not that common and its not easy to kill without alerting everyone.

1 is pretty good.
2 is way better with more memorable locations.3
3 is the most well known one but honestly a bit overrated mostly by people who only played 3.
4 is hit and miss, play/emulate the oldgen version (ps2/og Xbox) because its a different game compared to the PC/x360 one which is much worse.
Conviction is Jason Bourne: The game. Massive departure towards the action rooty tooty gameplay.
Blacklist is Conviction but not shit and not clunky. Great action game.
There are also some garbage games on PSP that are not necessary at all

Main character voice acting is GOAT, NPC voice acting is garbage.

Play the very first game. Get it on GOG, put a widescreen mod and play it. You will know within the first 30 minutes if you like it or not. They are very well made games that are polished to perfection. Mouse and keyboard work well.

>>9496654
Being poor third-worlders, at school we emulated the everloving shit out of those five games and G/S/C through VBA, usually sharing tips or teams. I played a common save in the library PC during recess with other three guys from my classroom, all doing a bit per day or picking one pokemon for the current team.
To be honest, I went through the 3rd gen games because I liked the new pokemons, it was my entry to 1st gen and I wanted to play more of the franchise, but it always felt like a downgrade to the GBC games; no visible day/night cycle, the gimmicky base building and contests and the music were things I didn't like over the simpler, more dynamic experience from the previous generation. I guess things would have been different if I had played them on the hardware and had traded and battled with other people as it was intended.
If I had to choose, though, it would be Emerald. The Battle Frontier was a great time sinker once you found that one place you liked and went through again and again, in my case being the Factory and renting pokemons.

>>9498630
I'm talking about something a lot greater than little callbacks or references. I'm talking about having a real plot and a main narrative that gets fleshed out, not reinvented, when Pokemon was brand new and not just another series that everybody knew the "rules" of how the franchise works, a lot of us viewed it differently. We expected our adventure in Gen1 and everything it presented from intriguing Pokemon bios, the cryptic story of Mew/Mewtwo etc, and even things from the anime to be laying the groundwork for some bigger narrative, but it wasn't...and that's where the disappointment lies. I remember being a kid and playing Saphire version and enjoying the gameplay well enough but just thinking "oh, so that's it....we're in a new region and there's a new narrative with new creatures, that really doesn't elaborate on or build off the last and creates its own new semi self contained story/mythology" and it was then I knew that's how Pokemon was going to work as a franchise, and it worked for them, keeping things fairly new each time is part of why it's so successful and easily adopted by each new era of kids, but it still disappointed a lot of us. If you came into Pokemon post Gen 1 when the rules of how Pokemon works as a franchise were established, it's probably hard to imagine a time when nobody knew that and assumed every little tiny detail in Gen 1 was a big deal that had something to do with a greater story

In retrospect, obviously not much thought went into the plot, but it didn't feel that way to us as little kids who took it very seriously

That's a tough choice. I think I'd have to go with FRLG over Emerald if only because I've replayed it more. It's been a long time since I've played either of these games though, and I liked both of them. I see Emerald as a better version of Ruby or Sapphire, but I also liked Ruby a lot.
This was easily my favorite generation of Pokemon games. I only played gens 1, 3, 4 and 6 though. I'm sure I missed out on some good stuff with GSC, but I at least played SoulSilver.

I should say that I both understand how FRLG seems like a soulless rehash to many people and personally think it's one of the nicest-looking, best-playing games in the series, if that makes sense. I played Red and Yellow before I played FireRed and honestly don't really prefer one version over the other. I think the original games had better music and a handful of better lines of dialogue, but FRLG was pretty great otherwise. I like held items, natures and all the other gen 3 junk and honestly like being able to play Red or Green with that stuff thrown in. I liked the way the Pokedex was presented and how the game gives you a little recap of what you last did whenever you load a save. The Sevii Islands were boring though, and the battle sprites should have been animated like they were in Emerald.

>>9501003
I liked Pearl but not enough to have ever replayed it since it came out. It was a really fun game during that first playthrough though, probably in part because me and my friends were battling and trading Pokemon. I don't remember the world map being quite as good as the ones in gen 3, but liked the story and all the new Pokemon. Some of my favorite Pokemon were introduced in those games now that I think about it. I hear Platinum is better, but I haven't played it.

>>9496654
I actually preferred Ruby/Sapphire because it at least was something new for its time. It did a lot of cool things and to me really freshened up the series up to that point. The only thing it missed was doing the physical/special split for attacks. That came a gen later. Would have been sweet to see it introduced with R/S/E instead. Was probably the most logical change to ever come to this franchise but by the time it showed up I was already done with Pokemon so I never played past the third gen of games. It was also nice to see those secret bases be a thing even if there was only a few limited locations for it. Was nice you could link up with friends, even have your friends character persist in your world. The fashion shows were also a fun divergence from the main game. Something this series desperately needed instead of just constant battling. Also made lesser mons and attacks not always completely worthless. Just too bad it was never expanded on really to my knowledge. Pokemon should have went out its way to vastly expand on concepts outside the catching and battling but I guess that leaves no room for milking so of course it wasn't happening.

Now as for the GB/GBC era, I actually prefer this era. Especially R/B/Y games. Its just preference and nostalgia admittedly. I also though prefer the look of this era to the later gens. Some gameplay and ideas from later games inserted into these older looking games instead would be perfect to me. One day I'll get around to those fan games or romhacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507662
>Was Halo really THAT fucking good?
Yes the original one was, not the sequels which were ads for the war on terror. The scope, atmosphere, vehicles, and the fact that you could see for miles within the game was very new. Before Halo you had... Shadows of the Empire, where you could use a jetpack intermittently or ride a motorbike during a level or two, but in Halo you could turn a level into a ghostbike/plane/sniper/sword level. So it combined genres like racing, shooting, and close-quarter platforming. Halo had a verticality that was stunning and it felt more like a strategy game where timing, coordination and close perception of the AI's movements all became decisive elements. One player would notice the AI doing one thing and the other player would see it doing something else and gradually its defensive wall would be pared back. Unlike the AI in 'Doom' or 'Shadows...', the AI in Halo seemed particularly animated, ingenious and funny. The atmospheric effects and textures brought everything much closer, the level design was repetitious but convincingly exotic. Also the sense of collaboration between immediate and later online friends was new. Booting up worms on the dc in 2001 was nothing like the hype surrounding halo 2 by Christmas 2004. In hindsight it's unfortunate that worms 3d wasn't postponed till 2005.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9507662
One look at the top sellers for the platform tells you everything. It was Halo machine first and foremost.
Remember that in N64 era, America was Nintendo's biggest market by far, making up like 60% of their sales (~20 million consoles out of ~32). They didn't sell well in Japan or Europe. And what was their biggest game in America? Right after Mario 64, it was Goldeneye. It was huge, bigger than Ocarina, MK64, etc.
In GC era, Nintendo lost its main multiplayer shooter, THE biggest game they had that wasn't Mario. Not surprisingly, their sales in America fell from 20 to 12.5 mln.
And then Xbox waltzed in, released with Halo, and eventually got Halo 2. It immediately got the crown of the "multiplayer FPS console". And given that Xbox was the "console for Americans" from the get go, it was bound to take away Nintendo's lead in their strongest market, and attract American 3rd parties well.
Xbox also easily beat GC in Yurop that never liked Nintendo and preferred me computahs.
Result: They beat Nintendo in America and Europe, and the few million GC sold in Japan meant shit in the end.

>>9494086
I mean, it did release in some form, but man, imagine how different the Sonic landscape might've been if Sonic Team had their priorities straight and swapped Sonic Adventure and NiGHTS into Dreams.
Saturn Adventure gets:
>a more focused, streamlined experience (ie. no techdemo crap like fishing)
>the swansong of the original character design aesthetic (or alternatively, the redesigns never happen because Sega wouldn't feel the need to reinvvent his image after skipping mainline 3D)
NiGHTS into Dreamcast gets:
>more exposure as a unique launch title and appropriately becomes the unofficial Dreamcast mascot
>Self content intact to extend the game's life
It's win-win.
BONUS: Sonic X-Treme potentially:
>gets further along in development due to the team not wasting weeks of work on the NiGHTS engine
>possibly far enough that Sega's PC division is interested in finishing it instead of turning it down as they did in this time-line

posts.com: VB Mario Land, or Mario Land, or whatever it was called. Basically Super Mario Land 4. It would've been released after Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land, and Wario would've returned to being the villain, which would've been interesting to see post-SML3 and could've impacted the future direction of his character. There were more console elements like Jumpin' Piranhas and flagpoles, as well as unique elements Mario never did before like Zelda-style interior overhead shots. Sadly, it supposedly got canned in favor of the Mario Clash minigame that became its own game (we have seen a pic of the Mario Bros.-style minigame, picrel, and it looked more like traditional Mario Bros. than 3-D Mario Bros., unless that minigame had multiple configurations).

>>9502203
MaskROM prices plummeted right in the middle of the 64DD's development. Nintendo wasn't expecting to be able to stick 32-64MB rom chips inside the cartridges at a reasonable cost so once that became viable the 64DD became redundant. Nintendo knew it, too. That's why they sold it through mail order and shit. Had they not been sitting on an already finished product they probably would have just canceled it outright.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sonic was in a catch-22 on the Saturn. The hardware wasn't powerful enough to do 3D sonic properly because that requires large levels and a decent framerate. 2D sonic on Saturn would've been amazing, but at the time I can see how this would've been viewed as a laughing stock while everyone else was jumping on the 3D bandwagon and 2D was seen as lame shit for flaghship platformers.

Still though, I would've loved to see 2D sonic on Saturn. Imagine something like Sonic Mania but the game world is split into separate "layers" like background/middle/foreground and sonic can move between different paths on these layers. I think there's even a Mania level that does something like this, imagine that but fully fleshed out

posts.com:
It's ok.
It seems like a game that had troubled development.
The engine seems like it had 0 playtesting. Almost every mechanic in this game has at least 1 thing off about them.
I've had a few game overs from the rails, Light Dash, and vine swings just flat out not working correctly.
The difference in levels for each of the teams aren't really too different enough to justify playing every stage 4+ times.
Speed character is fun, but 75% ends in a falling death.
The Bonus Emerald stage and Pinball controls are some of the worst things in any video game.

That being said, some of the mechanics are fun, the jank and repeating voice lines can be funny or charming at times, the graphics and music are nice and it runs smoothly.
This coming from someone who finished it the other day.

I especially love Rail Canyon and Egg Fleet when you can just jump out into the skybox and land on a rail.

Once you get used to the jank in the controller it I think its fun and you can pull off some cool moves. Biggest issue is playing all stories takes too long just to see the real ending. Still done it 3 times That and the Bonus stages being genuinely shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's alright, but for what it's trying to be some of the levels really outstay their welcome. I think it's great that they tried to go back to the Genesis format instead of just doing Sonic Adventure 3. For the first few levels, it really is a blast to shoot through the levels in whichever way you see fit. I recall there being lots of branching paths and different ways of approaching a level depending on which team member you have selected.

The big problem comes later on in the game when enemy health gets so fucking bloated that you have to stop the pace and hammer away at these enemies for upwards of 10-20 seconds (a hell of a lot of time to be stopped in a Sonic game), even if you had all team members fully leveled. This problem is magnified with the sheer size of some of the levels towards the end of the campaigns. A lot of the reason they take so long to beat is because of all the forced combat with massive enemies. And the last few levels weren't really all that interesting to boot. Compound that with the fact that you basically have to play the same levels four times to fully beat the game, and it got really tiring after a while. For a single playthrough? Sure, it's a fun time. But I'd never willingly completely beat the game ever again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hear me out... This was an experiment, and I think it went well.
I heard the Family Pocket was a fun and convenient device for the money and I thought "bullshit" but tried it because I was looking for cheaper gifts at the time and didn't want to setup and/or build a new device for the 50th time. It's not fun anymore.
I did take out the decoy cartridge and I did throw some other games on to test these silly Java emulators for NeoGeo and SNES, but that's it.
Metal Slug doesn't work. It won't pass the Yoshi's Island test, but I played Earthbound and Mario All Stars fine. Every GBC I've tried ran fine. All the NES and Genesis so far run fine.

It's all setup out of the box with a functioning UI in English, decent lists with boxart, easy save slot for each game, and instant on/off that (so far) seems to be about as safe as possible. I didn't swap the loaded SD for a better one yet so who knows? But six months of testing so far and no worries. I paid $25 for it. It looks and feels like a pickup and play toy and it is. Which I love.

I have several anbernic devices and so on, I'm not a pleb. I'm just sharing my findings on this. It's a really neat convenient affordable toy if you like the proposition.

(Also on a personal note, I love the sound. It isn't good although it has a vol wheel. But the mostly empty softer plastic case seems to smooth out all the bumpy squares and triangles in the sound waves of 8-16 bit games that make my ears thump uncomfortably without a great setup. I have this issue on my 351p with all settings possible tweaked. The smoothing resonance of the cheap case is a nice bonus for me.)
Thank you for liking and subscribing to my autistic review bastard blog

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9505037
Depends. Fighting games generally have an arcade mode that has you fight AIs but older especially tend to have hard ones, especially if you play the arcade versions. Some fighting games also have difficulty settings in the options, which could help to ease you in, depending on the game.
I'm far from an expert, but speaking personally, I found that Soulcalibur and Capcom vs SNK helped me quite a bit: SCI gives you a decent amount of moves to do through buttons and directionals rather than inputs and the Groove system in Capcom vs SNK was what pushed me to learn how inputs work (although getting to Akuma was next to impossible for me until I got lucky). The A.I. in CvS1 can be hard if it gets in the mood though (Ryu in particular is a pain in the ass, but still doable if you aren't worrying about Groove too much).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494516
I don't find fighting games a lot of fun to play in single player desu, I think it's because they rely so much on reading your opponent and trying not to get read yourself, and that element just doesn't really exist against a CPU beyond figuring out their rudimentary pattern. You can't mix up a CPU, and whether you block their mix-up can come down to pure luck whereas against a human it's not ALL luck, even if it's unreactable. If enemies in single-player action games had unreactable mix-ups it'd be considered pure BS and that's what you're dealing with sometimes when playing against CPUs. It's like playing poker against a computer, it feels kinda pointless.

Although doing combos against CPUs can be fun, since in most fighting games once you begin a combo the game essentially becomes a single-player rhythm game until the combo ends. Fighting games are a weird genre.

>>9506456
No, they're all just walking meat sacks you grab from the bar that never speak or do anything meaningful. DQ3 is the simplest, most basic DQ besides the first one, and that's part of the reason it's so beloved. You gotta remember, it's not a SNES game at heart. It's a Famicom game. Since you don't want spoilers, I'll say that there's one thing that happens during the last stretch of the game that would make Gen X Japanese kids shit their pants when they realized what was going on, but again, that's because this is a Famicom game and the first time said trope was utilized. If you like what you're playing but want something a little bit more substantial, DQ9 on the DS is kind of like the Bravely Default to DQ3's Final Fantasy V. You have a real main character, a bunch of meat sacks from the inn to join your adventure, but there's an actual plot with stakes, NPCs, cutscenes, and you can customize how your character looks with armour/weapons changing their appearance as well.

Also, I think this was a poor time to try to play DQ3. Even though the SNES version is the best version of the game available to play right now, that's going to change relatively soon since it's getting a HD2D remake like Live-A-Live recently got.

It was already censored.
But they still can censor it even further.

They were already censored back in 2014 for the mobile localization of 1+2+3, and the censorship was backported to the Japanese text. (In fact a little known fact was that the 3DS versions are internally fully localized, but Square Enix refused to release it either way)

The censorship covers every single game localized by Plus Alfa, except for VIII (their very first). It's mainly the puff-puff jokes and "comments demeaning to women" (such as the whore near the church, or the vengeful scorned tranny, or the fake puff puff between man tits), and it's so bad the only games that went unscathed are the NES games 1-4 partially (a complete translation of the intent, but some lines were changed while the others still gave away the full intent as if it was sloppy censorship on purpose), their Game Boy Color ports, 7, 8 and that's it. No way to know if the scrapped Enix USA localizations of 6 and 4 would have been good as well, since they're unreleased and sitting in a vault somewhere.

Around XI they said "no puff puff was censored" and that the localization was authentic, but in fact promotional content for the 3DS XI version had a callback to one of the classic cut puff puff jokes that was changed in the final version, the faggot character was actually giving any males he found feminine names in the jp version, and entire novel side content were cut.

posts.com: What systems were these buttons present on? I've only heard of "turbo button" to refer to autofire buttons on controllers, this downclocked the console to play older titles?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9510885
AFAIK they were exclusively a PC phenomenon. The original IBM PC was clocked at 4.77 MHz, and a lot of software developed for it relied on that clock speed for timings. Once newer IBM PCs and PC compatibles came to market with newer, faster processors, however, said older software would end up running much too fast, thus necessitating a way to downclock the CPU to the expected 4.77 MHz. Thus the Turbo button was added to most systems made from around the 80286 era up to the Pentium era. Depending on how it was wired, toggling it on would actually result in downclocking, or it would run the machine at its normal speed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9510953
More or less this, but halving a 20MHz 386 down to 10MHz wasn't going to fix the problem of not running at 4.77MHz. It was still for compatibility though, since devs were still making programs tied to CPU speed. I remember the space combat game Epic would run perfectly fine when I had CPU speed on my 486 halved to 33MHz, but would run too fast to keep up with or be playable at the full 66MHz.
It was the first step in getting a game to run at the right speed if it was tied to CPU. First you hit the button to see if that would slow things down enough. If that didn't work, then you turned to Moslo and similar programs to slow things down to the right speed. You just hoped the button would solve the problem so you didn't have to jump through those hoops.

>>9494075
You're in luck anon, here's the definitive classic-style Castlevania guide.
>Castlevania 1 (NES)
Great game, and if you could beat this one you can handle most of the ones after.
>Castlevania 2: Simon's Quest (NES)
Don't bother, it's rather boring. The progression is generally pretty obtuse and you'd think the dungeon levels would be the fun action levels but nope, they just suck and don't even have cool unique aesthetics.
>Castlevania 3: Dracula's Curse (NES)
The best 8-bit Castlevania, with multiple routes and playable characters. Play the Japanese version for a richer soundtrack, slightly better graphical effects, and a more tough-but-fair challenge as originally intended.
>Super Castlevania 4 (SNES)
Surprisingly underrated these days, my personal favorite Classicvania. The graphics and sound are awesome and the gameplay is fun as hell, with more streamlined controls. It is easier than usual for Castlevania which makes it more approachable to just sit back and play, but if you love the hardcore challenge of previous Castlevania games you may be disappointed.
>Castlevania: Rondo of Blood (TG-CD)
The fan favorite Classicvania. Whereas SC4 went full on with the Halloween horror aesthetic, this one goes full early-90s anime and it's a really fun vibe. It's on a CD so it's got voice acted cutscenes and CD quality music. The controls are more stiff than SC4, and the challenge is cranked back up, but it still feels a little more fair than the NES games. Alternate routes are back and you can unlock a second character.
>Castlevania Chronicles (X68000, PS1)
Okay reimagining of the first game. The difficulty here is retardedly high, and it's just the worst 16-bit Castlevania by far. The PS1 version adds an """easy""" mode but the music for that mode is really goofy remixes.
>Castlevania Bloodlines (Genesis)
This one's pretty fun, and it's on Genesis so it feels a little more "hardcore". Not as classic as 4 or Rondo but worth playing.

>both the official translation, the translation on that wiki AND the "super accurate retranslation you need to use because you'll get stuck otherwise" fuck up the ONLY goddamn thing the official translation actually mistranslated in a way that actively hurts your chances of beating the game
Holy shit.

(ブンケン does not mean "clue", it means "book". The people telling you "clues to Dracula's riddle are in (location)" are actually supposed to be telling you there's one or more hidden books in that location that you should be looking for. Not understanding that means you probably won't find the book that tells you how to use the blue crystal, which means you'll get stuck because that's not a solution you'll magically stumble over)

posts.com:
>>9508123
Luck Mode is Hard Mode, except getting enemy drops is way easier. It's simultaneously a harder difficulty if you ever want to replay the game and a "okay, you already beat the game, drop rates don't need to be ridiculously low anymore, you can grab whatever you want" mechanism. CotM does it too, and every game from Aria onward calls it Hard Mode but also ups your drop rates.

posts.com:
>>9506921
Those are the game files with the audio files in either .mp3 or .wav format. I don't think any emulator will work with .mp3 so get the wav version. You will need a core to emulate the TurboGrafx-16, also known as the PC Engine. Download any of the NEC - PC Engine cores (Beetle PCE, Beetle PCE FAST, or Beetle SuperGrafx, any of them should work) through retroarch. You then load the content by choosing the Akumajou Dracula X - Chi no Rondo (J).cue file and picking whichever core you chose. Chances are if you follow these directions as I've written them, retroarch will immediately crash right after you choose the core to run the cue file with. This is because those emulators don't work without a BIOS. Use google and find a bios pack. Searching "retroarch complete bios pack" should get you something. You want the loose files directly in the "system" directory of your retroarch install. Should be some 256KB files names syscard**.pce, one called gecard.pce and another called gexpress.pce. You can get a BIOS pack at https://github.com/Abdess/retroarch_system/releases/download/v20220308/libretro_31-01-22.zip (which I found from https://emulation.gametechwiki.com/index.php/Emulator_files) but bear in mind the BIOS files are neatly organized by category, which of course doesn't work because why would anything work in a way that's neat and organized? I have some other pack that extracts to a nice flat mess just how retroarch likes it. Anyway, just copy everything in the NEC - PC Engine - TurboGrafx 16 - SuperGrafx folder and paste it into the "[Folder where retroarch.exe is]/system" folder and you should be good to go. The opening voiceover is in german but all the text should be translated into english.

>>9507801
Dark Sun: Shattered Lands has a great dialogue/quest system. Every problem you encounter has multiple potential solutions based on your choices and your party composition. For example, there are many ways to escape the slave pens at the start: sneak your way out, fight your way out directly, or join forces with one of the slave gangs and work within their plans. It's like a proto-Deus Ex.

Most earlier D&D games were nothing but dungeon crawlers where you slaughter everything you encounter (and I do enjoy those) but Dark Sun gave the player meaningful choices.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493759
Lots of reasons. It's been known since forever ago that Woolsey didn't deliver the most faithful translation, not to mention all the censorship, which is why we got that old Sky Render fan translation over twenty years ago (that we now know to be amateurish as fuck). Then the GBA game came out, and its translation was recognized to be much more accurate, but it had two problems: first, by that point, Woolsey's script had obtained meme status, and while the GBA script kept some of his lines, it changed or tossed enough of them out to piss a vocal part of the fanbase off. Second, the GBA version had problems of its own, namely shit music, slowdown and lower resolution, among others. So now you have a bunch of Woolsey fanboys who like the idea of a more accurate script while still staying true to the Woolsey "flavor", all on the mostly superior SNES version, and before long, we got the Ted Woolsey Uncensored hack. Problem is, its creator didn't know a lick of moon, so all he did was mix and match bits and pieces of the Woolsey, GBA and Sky Render scripts as he pleased, and to top it off, he decided to also make it an overarching "game improvement" hack that fixed a gorillion longstanding bugs and added QoL changes. This effectively set the mold for all like-minded hacks that followed, all of which were made by people with no nip-speaking credentials, and all of which were convinced they could do it better than the last, especially given they're not constrained to just script changes, but outright game changes as well, so every new release is just feature creep. It's telling that it wasn't until like last year that we got a simple, no frills port of the GBA script to the SNES version.

tl;dr autism and one-upmanship

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9508660
The 8-bit games are a special case because their coding was full of holes like a Swiss cheese and so they hardly hold up in their original form. Your best bet for the first two games are either the WonderSwan Color OR PlayStation versions. They are the closest to the original gameplay while having appropriate bugfixes and not comprising the experience like later releases. Final Fantasy III is in a horrible position because its WonderSwan remake was canceled and so there is no alternative 2D version until now. You can play either the Famicom original OR the Pixel Remaster. In many ways, it is the only PR that really matters, though note that the experience is altered from the original as it lifts a few changes from the 3D version, although admittedly they chose the few changes that (mostly) worked.
Beyond the 8-bit trilogy always play original, fuck the rest.

>>9509053
The only people who think 64 is better are boomers who grew up with it and dumb contrarians. Anyone else can see what is plainly obvious. I tried watching a PM64 playthrough a year or two ago (I played the game myself a long time back) and I was surprised by how dull and soulless the dialogue was in comparison to TTYD’s. And that’s not all: TTYD’s characters and partners are better, the story is better, the chapters are more creative and interesting, the visuals (naturally) are better, the music is better, so on and so forth. And the game is a bit darker too, which is fun. The only real shortcomings of the game are the backtracking and repetitive hallway-like level design. It surpasses 64 in virtually every other respect.

When people consider the series as a whole, they imagine TTYD and 64 at the pinnacle, towering over everything else, with Super somewhere halfway down and basically everything else at the bottom. If you ask me, 64 belongs down with Super. You want to talk about an outdated game living off of nostalgia, look no further than that…

Boomers can assert that “their” game is the best game in a given series for various different franchises—Mario, Zelda, DKC, etc.—but Paper Mario is one in which they simply have no argument whatsoever, and nobody really takes them seriously.

My order seeks a balance between getting power-ups early and reducing backtracking:

1. Chill Penguin
2. Storm Eagle
3. Flame Mammoth
4. Launch Octopus
5. Sting Chameleon
6. Boomer Kuwanger

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember thinking the concept for these was really cool; like >>9501486 says, having the screen overlaying a 3D backdrop is a nice step up from a 2D vpet thing on a blank or barely visible background, and it’s a shame that concept wasn’t explored more before tech and the market seemed to move on to other gimmicks. According to a youtube reviewer who covers late 90s/early 2000s electronics, there were several neat easter eggs built into their design—not only were there the obligatory cashgrab interconnectivity gimmicks where you could connect devices to have one girl visit another’s house or go into a car/mall/whatever, but even just with one the little light in the upstairs window turns on a few seconds after she ascends the stairs to go to bed. The speakers were impressive too; they supported voice acting (by Tara Strong apparently) while other vpets were still limited to high-pitched beeps.
…When these were advertised, my horny teenage brain once dreamt that a line of these came out with different devices which catered to different fetishes. Part of me still thinks that there’s a market to be had for an adult version of these where you take care of your own virtual bored housewife or whatever.
I know these are a loose definition of /vr/ which is sure to incite arguments among “letter of the law” vs “spirit of the law” anons, even though it’s retro from within the right era and they’re just as much games as Game&Watch devices were; but I want to hear about other v-pet devices from this era, especially if they were able to connect with more traditional gaming devices. An anon on /toy/ vaguely described being able to connect modern day digivices to the original PS and Wonderswan games, but apparently several adapters are necessary to accomplish that.

As for being buffed, if you get so in debt from continuously failing you will be given Human Plus mode, which removes certain restrictions such as weight limits and allows you to use certain weapons on the move.

For AC3 and up
right arm weapon (Square): Left Mouse Button

Look Up/Down (L2, R2): Mouse Y-Axis (-)/(+) (in that order)
Look Left/Right (D-Left/D-Right): Mouse X-Axis (-)/(+)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played the PS1 game when I was like... 7 years old, and I really liked building my robot. That stuff was really compelling. The customisation is the real meat on the bones of this game, which is fortunate because the gameplay itself was pretty weak. But in fairness, I can't criticise it too harshly for that, it's only like when you play a mediocre RPG because you still get that nice dopamine hit from getting sweet loot.

To me, a real mech game should have a cockpit view and obtuse controls that make you really feel like you're a PILOT, not just that you're playing as a sentient robot. If they can pull off something that feels a bit more realistic and less weeby, I might be more interested.

But yeah, I think there are a lot of hipsters who claim the game is better than it is because it's FromSoft, much like with King's Field. I find it funny because they act like FromSoft have always had this enlightened genius game design when in reality, like most successes, Dark Souls was just kind of a lucky experimental combination of the right ingredients.

>>9511449
Do you even understand what a RNG is?
Let's say you have 75% of chances to succeed.
A random number between 0 and 100 will be generated by the RNG when you leave a stage.
If this number is between 0 and 75, you will succeed, if the number is between 76 and 100, you will fail.

This result is already pre-determined before you choose to fire the laser/launch the rocket, but it is RNG regardless.

He gets way more hate than he deserves. I know Spoony hated him but to be honest I always liked him back in the day. I didn't really dislike anyone but Rinoa and Quistis. Quistis mainly for being such a fuck-up on her mission. Irvine is alright and his choke is one of the few things made better by the bad plot twist about the orphanage. On that topic...

FF8 is my most nostalgic Final Fantasy. It's the first one I really played and the first one I ever saw played by anyone else. I was stoked to finally own it in 1999 or 2000, whenever it was I got a PS1 (the slim release). That said, I do think it is ultimately a badly designed game. I think FF8 would have benefited greatly from another six months to a year of development to rework the mechanics and tune the story. It's a good story, but falls a little short in places.

Also, the English translation should not have butchered so much of Squall's dialog.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499552
The only ones I find a chore are a small portion of Tall, Tall Mountain, and mostly the tiny side of Tiny, Huge Island.

TTM is too linear with ascending the mountain, and the camera angle is a little annoying for stuff like the red coins.

THM is just a nuisance to navigate as it can be too easy to slip up and fall off the island, because it's just too tiny.
Part of the problem is that the game's controls were fine tuned to the original N64 analogue stick which has a huge pivot. Modern controls have a much smaller pivot so finer movements on N64 games are unreliable. Think stuff like Bow and Arrow aiming in Ocarina of Time / Majora's Mask, it's an issue that persists in official releases like Wii Virtual Console.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495706
Adding more objectives on higher difficulties is the only good option the designers had. It's boring to just add more guards on a higher difficulty (which it does, but it's secondary to the new objectives) or the even worse option of changing their behavior. You're playing a stealth game, so the inability to kill guards is important to make sure you stay undetected and be more careful instead of: "Oh well, I was careless and got caught, time for a sword fight!" Having to get in a sword fight (or run away on difficulties that prevent killing) works, because Thief (or more accurately Thief 1) is meant to evoke tension and fear of getting caught and to stray you away from confrontation. The blackjack (note: there is no specific spot you have to hit guards with it, you can do it from any direction, even the front, provided they aren't in combat) works as a mechanic, because the choice to use it or not use it changes the way the game it played, if you knock guards out you get the burden of hiding their bodies, so other AI don't see them. And if you choose to not use the blackjack, then the only suitable playstyle is ghosting (not alerting anyone to the point where they start to search for you) which makes the game even more difficult to those who desire while also changing the way you play.
The beauty of Thief comes down to letting the player form a playstyle without having them pick a class or such, but from the game's mechanics, Thief gives you so much freedom of approach while only making restrictions when necessary.

The sound designers for Thief were in a band signed with Warner Bros so they probably knew a ton about mixing from being around their engineers.
