>>9502898
I don't agree with the magnitude of this opinon, but I do agree with the intent. If the game isn't fun to 100% then don't do it. Enjoy it for what it is or was, rather than ruining your taste for it with overexposure.

As for dicking you over, I don't know that Rare was that bad. They cut their teeth in computing, and in my experience computer games are typically much crueler about secrets or about execution skill. Part of it I think is the hardware and the audience; Scrolling was a challenge on computers for years and years (while NES/etc. had dedicated hardware for it) and adults were more likely to own computers (in the US at least; Europe was more slanted toward all ages of course). At least for US output, however, that meant that you were more likely to get slower, thought-provoking games, rather than faster, dexterity-challenging games. Given a lack of space, however, you'd want to make the agme particularly cruel in its mental demands, since action-oriented play wasn't as feasible. So you end up with Wizardry rather than Makaimura, as two arbitrary examples.

>>9504526
this whole thread is torn apart by the simple of notion of "X but in a good way". There is no universal standard for acceptable or unacceptable terms of challenge in a game. There is no such thing as challenge which everyone agrees upon being fair or unfair, because what "fair" and "unfair" really boil down to is "this is challenge that I find fun" vs. "this is challenge that I don't find fun".

The entire notion of challenges being good ones is built upon what someone is feeling as they play and can't be argued away as a constant. Widely held rules can only provide some margin of guidance at best.

God, don't remind me; I did the exact same shit just hoping to find anything. JFG was fucking atrocious at giving any kind of direction. On top of the stuff outlined here >>9507336 another thing that I noticed on my replay that pissed me the hell off was the bear on the water ruins planet.

There's this bear character there who mentions he is bothered by the tribals in the area making noise and he wishes he had some earplugs. If you pester him long enough; And I mean, exhausting every dialouge option and then talking to him AGAIN he'll finally mention he heard there were some on the SS Anubis level.

So you get to SS Anubis and scour the entire place. Guess what? They aren't actually anywhere in the level. They are the reward for the Floyd mission of this level which is baffling for a multitude of reasons

A: The game makes absolutely no mention anywhere that Earplugs are the reward here, not even in the fucking Floyd mission description itself
B: Compounding this, the game has previously never locked a collectible behind a Floyd mission so you have no reason to think to look here in the first place
C: In order to even get the earplug reward you need to finish the mission with the highest rank which is hard as balls
D: Even if you complete it, unless you finish it with the highest rank you still get no hint that you can even get the earplugs from this mission in the first place

Rare were just fucking around at this point, its insane for me to imagine this was supposed to be figured out by kids

Fucking NES games were less cryptic than this shit

>what are her essential episodes?

She's been showing up more and more in recent seasons. Season 24 Mini-corner was her as an astrologer, using a PlayStation astrology game. Arino must not like psychics and astrology though, because he consistently passive aggressively sabotages the segments.

She tried to help in the Sailor Moon challenge. Occasionally shows up in trip segments in a few recent season translated episodes.

She reveals in the Clock Tower: Ghost Head challenge that when she was a little girl, her father owned a PlayStation, and she would watch him play the game but he never got a good ending in it.

She mentions that Dragon's Lair was highly requested, so getting the rights to an American game was difficult. This implies that her official job of "Public relations" means she negotiates the rights from other companies. Previously, I wasn't sure what her actual job was, and had assumed PR meant running the social media page or something.

>>9502335
Season 1 changes a bit as it progresses. The first few episodes just has Arino playing a game for a few minutes of the episode, but starting with episode 5 he gets proper challenges they actually dedicate real screentime to, and in episode 10 they spend more or less half the episode on "Arino beats Super Mario Bros and tries to beat Super Mario Bros 2", which then got a follow-up in the post-season special where he challenges SMB2 again.
Season 2 then makes the game challenge the main part of the episode and the dev interviews the minor segment, and then season 3 replaces the dev interviews with season-specific segments.

Unfortunately only half of season 1 is fully subbed, with the rest of season 1 and all of season 2 only having garbage guess subs, which makes watching the show from the beginning a bit of a pain.

posts.com: it's the same genre

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9509285
>>9509457

There's two definitions of hack n slash. One is that they are just what happened when beat em ups went full 3D. For whatever reason most 2D beat em ups were about punching and kicking while most 3D beat em ups involved some sort of melee weapon. There was no reason for this trend other then that the early popular games in the genre set the trend.

The other definition of hack n slash is a type of RPG that is focused heavily on combat and looting. NPC interaction and any mechanics/items not directly related to combat are kept to a minimum. Areas were less about being a neat maze or a fantasy land of lore and more of just a giant planes of monsters. Diablo pretty much perfected this game philosophy. Gauntlet is also called a hack n slash, despite not being an RPG, it has the same feeling that the hack n slash philosophy was going for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9509285
I was thinking about this and we had beat em ups as a popular genre, but the hardware limitations kind of forced it to be a "beat em up" as in fewer enemies that can really hit you, the slower pacing, etc... When we got more powerful hardware, people were impressed by the higher number of enemies, faster gameplay with more exaggerated combos and shit (which has a different appeal from beat em ups imo), so it was kind of an evolution of the genre, wasn't it?
Hack n Slash games have kind of killed beat em ups for a few generations because of that, but now I feel like both of them have their own space (or at least beat em ups are starting to get it back)
I don't KNOW what I am saying, I'm just kind of thinking out loud.

Some of them do a lot of shit behind the curtains so they can be more authentic, breaking the image own into red, green and blue channels and combining them, applying halation, glow, blur, curvature, scanline shape, etc. all in separate passes, like stacking blocks building up the final image.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487747
If it was just an overlay of lines, it'd be nothing.
But a proper shader is separating red, green, and blue signals for each pixel into separate phosphors, applying distortion onto the overall image, specific blending properties based on adjacent colors, etc. And all of this has to be done to every pixel on every rendered frame.
On top of the game being played in the first place, it's a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You don't need to own a CRT just to enjoy playing retro games. You could be emulating old games on your phone or PC or MiSTer or Android/x86 handheld or you could be playing with real hardware, as long as you're having fun that's what matters most.
With that said, I feel like some games play better, or at least they dont feel as laggy on a CRT like they do on higher res LCD panels. Plus some consoles like the PS2 generally look like shit no matter what upscaler or cables you shell out for. PS2 component cables + a Retrotink 5X at full 1080p/1440p makes it "presentable looking" I guess, but it isnt a huge upgrade in my eyes to just plugging in the included composite cables and just gaming on a dinky 13" CRT.

Upscalers are good to have if theres no good/cheap/free CRTs in your area, and they are much better than just plugging it into your TV in terms of image quality and performance, but they aren't going to magically turn your existing games into HD Remasters. if thats what you want then just emulate or buy the HD ports/PC versions if the option is available and they're of good quality.

Finally, you don't need to overspend on a Retrotink 5X or an OSSC just to have a good experience. Just grab a GBS Control, or a Retrotink 2X Mini.
https://www.retrotink.com/product-page/2x-mini

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9499306
Something I didn't see others mention that is a huge part of beat em ups is the fact that they are meant to be played by more than one person, with many even going as far as having 4 (and even sometimes even 6) sticks so many people could play at the same time.
The amount of fun playing with 3 more people in a cabinet is hard to explain. With all the monsters, the fighting for the powerups and health, saving a buddy by dropping with a new live/bomb drop, and all the hectic stuff going around.
Playing solo is simply not the same experience. I recommend trying to play them coop with a friend online, physically together would be even better.

As for a specific game, one of my favourites is Alien vs Predator.
It has the perfect amount of complexity in character moves and enemy patterns / powerups that you can always come out of a game session feeling like you got better and the next time you could squeeze more moves/better play from your character.
It's an important part of the experience too because beat em ups that are too simple get boring really fast if the only thing you do is press punch over and over with the occasional powerup and enemy that takes a ton of hits.

Turtles in Time and (not retro) Dragon's Crown are amazing too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>don't enjoy beat-em-ups
Everyone's recommending the D&D arcade games because they have an inventory system to add a layer to the gameplay. Also check out River City Ransom, which adds in an RPG-ish system of money, items, and upgrades. Aliens VS Predator leans heavily into weaponry over mashing the attack button. Die Hard Arcade is similar but also has special combo attacks worth learning. Battle Circuit is a bit like RCR, but without the ability to grind. Armored Warriors lets you use defeated enemy's weapons.
Don't play generic jump-and-attack-to-win games like Simpsons, X-Men, or Oriental Legends/Knights of Valour. They are flashy but just button mashers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9503276
>70s
That would be the Intellivision, it had really advanced games for its time and price range. There's also the Atari 400/800, they were designed to be console/computer hybrid with really advanced capability far beyond anything many years after its launch, even the master system couldn't compete against its 2.5D capability. Star Raiders, released in 1979 in an 8KB cart, was an absolute showstopper, people couldn't believe it's an actual video game. It cost a fortune, but it's worth every cent. Still a lot cheaper than Apple II anyway.
>80s
There's a lot to choose from, but I would consider the C64 to be the definitive system of the whole 80s. It was affordable, it had really impressive games, and the software library is truly endless. Just like the Atari 400/800, I consider it a console/computer hybrid. From a strictly technical perspective, I gotta give it to the Vectrex, it's incredibly fast and smooth and plays even better than most arcade games. Shame about the small library.

>it was console gaming that crashed.

It crashed because retailers were sick of the shit that Atari was pushing in the retail space. That really about sums it up. Even Atari had to switch over to the home computer market for a few decades. Nintendo had a hard enough time getting the NES into the US retail market, because retail outlets were still weary of the game consoles that came before it. Nintendo had to force a lot of restrictions on third parties and continually assure that the games are good and wouldn't see a lot of refunds.

They say it 'crashed' because the successor to the 2600, the 5200, only sold one million units. It's disingenuous, like saying the market crashed in 2001 when Gamecube and Dreamcast failed to find buyers (which is much closer to the truth, since they weren't repackaging the same games that you were playing five years before under different IP labels like Atari).
